revision.comment: /* Early life */ clarifying edit to make clear that the college is an entity within the larger university
revision.text:
{{short description|American comedic actress}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}} {{Infobox person | name = Maya Rudolph | image = Maya_Rudolph.jpg | caption = Rudolph in 2012 at the [[Paley Center for Media]] | birth_name = Maya Khabira Rudolph | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1972|7|27}} | birth_place = [[Gainesville, Florida]], U.S. | residence = [[San Fernando Valley, California]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] | occupation = {{hlist|Actress|comedian|singer}} | years_active = 1996–present | partner = [[Paul Thomas Anderson]]
(2001–present){{efn|Rudolph refers to Anderson as husband.{{cite web|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/maya-rudolph-paul-thomas-anderson-married/|title=Maya Rudolph Reveals Why She Calls Paul Thomas Anderson Her "Husband" Even Though They Are Not Married|work=W|publisher=Condé Nast|date=September 14, 2018|last=Marine|first=Brooke|access-date=February 6, 2020}}}} | children = 4 | parents = [[Richard Rudolph]]
[[Minnie Riperton]] | website = }} '''Maya Khabira Rudolph''' (born July 27, 1972) is an American actress, comedian, and singer. She first gained prominence in the mid-1990s as a member of the alternative rock band [[The Rentals]], before joining [[The Groundlings]] [[improvisational theatre|improv]] troupe later in the decade. In 2000, Rudolph became a cast member on the [[NBC]] late-night sketch comedy series ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' and subsequently appeared in supporting roles in films such as ''[[50 First Dates]]'' (2004),{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2004/film/markets-festivals/50-first-dates-1200536452/|title=50 First Dates|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|date=February 13, 2004|website=Variety|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 9, 2020}} ''[[A Prairie Home Companion (film)|A Prairie Home Companion]]'' (2006), and ''[[Idiocracy]]'' (2006).{{cite book |chapter=Maya Rudolph |title=The Complete Marquis Who's Who|publisher=[[Marquis Who's Who]]|year=2010|accessdate=September 24, 2011 |chapter-url=http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/bic1/ReferenceDetailsPage/ReferenceDetailsWindow?displayGroupName=Reference&disableHighlighting=false&prodId=BIC2&action=e&windowstate=normal&catId=&documentId=GALE%7CK2014901123&mode=view&userGroupName=fairfax_main&jsid=b5fad977fb57dfcbc27feef7d1f146cb |id=Gale Document Number: GALE K2014901123 |chapter-format=fee, via [[Fairfax County Public Library]]}} [[Gale (publisher)|Gale]] Biography In Context. After leaving ''Saturday Night Live'' in 2007, Rudolph appeared in various films, including ''[[Grown Ups (film)|Grown Ups]]'' (2010) and its [[Grown Ups 2|2013 sequel]], ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' (2011), ''[[Inherent Vice (film)|Inherent Vice]]'' (2014), ''[[Sisters (2015 film)|Sisters]]'' (2015), ''[[CHiPs (film)|CHiPs]]'' (2017), [[Life of the Party (2018 film)|''Life of the Party'']] (2018), and ''[[Wine Country (film)|Wine Country]]'' (2019). She also lent her voice to the animated films ''[[Shrek the Third]]'' (2007), ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]'' (2014), ''[[The Angry Birds Movie]]'' (2016) and its [[The Angry Birds Movie 2|2019 sequel]], ''[[The Emoji Movie]]'' (2017), and ''[[The Willoughbys]]'' (2020). In addition to her film appearances, Rudolph starred as Ava Alexander in the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Up All Night (TV series)|Up All Night]]'' (2011-2012), and co-hosted her own variety series ''[[Maya & Marty]]'' (2016) with [[Martin Short]]. Since 2017, she has voiced various characters in the [[Big Mouth (TV series)|''Big Mouth'']] animated series. Since 2018, Rudolph has appeared in the NBC fantasy comedy series ''[[The Good Place]]'', for which she received two [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series]]. ==Early life== Rudolph was born in [[Gainesville, Florida]], to singer-songwriter [[Minnie Riperton]] and composer [[Richard Rudolph]].{{cite web|url=http://www.interfaithfamily.com/arts_and_entertainment/popular_culture/hollywood_now_interfaith_celeb_news_maya_rudolph.shtml|title=Hollywood Now: Interfaith Celebs Maya Rudolph, Lea Michele & - InterfaithFamily|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/31/Maya-Rudolph.html |title=Maya Rudolph Biography (1972–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=January 2, 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vTgVAAAAIBAJ&pg=5271,2678552&dq=essence-of-lucinda |title=The Essence of Lucinda |date=June 6, 2001 |work=[[Ocala Star-Banner]] |accessdate=November 11, 2013}} Her mother was [[African-American]] and her father is [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazi Jewish]]. Her paternal grandfather was Sidney Rudolph, a philanthropist who once owned all of the [[Wendy's]] and Rudy's restaurants in [[Miami-Dade County, Florida]].{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB3484EE61794FE&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Sidney J. Rudolph, Philanthropist and Restaurant Owner |date=December 23, 1992 |work=[[Miami Herald]]}} Her great-grandfather was born in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]], changed his surname from "Rudashevsky" to "Rudolph", and was one of the founding members of Congregation Beth Shalom, a [[Conservative Jewish]] synagogue in the [[Squirrel Hill]] neighborhood of [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]].Stated by [[Henry Louis Gates]] on the ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'' episode "In Search of Freedom," January 19, 2016, PBS Rudolph's parents moved to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], when she and her brother Marc were very young, and they grew up primarily in the [[Westwood, Los Angeles|Westwood]] neighborhood.{{cite news| last=Itzkoff| first=Dave| title=Juggling a Comedy Series About Juggling Life's Tasks| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/11/arts/television/maya-rudolph-appears-in-the-series-up-all-night.html?pagewanted=1| accessdate=September 10, 2011| date=September 9, 2011| work=The New York Times}} Near the end of the song "[[Lovin' You]]", Riperton can be heard singing "Maya" over and over again. Riperton incorporated this into her performance of the song on ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]''.{{cite video |people=[[Minnie Riperton]] |date=1975 | title=Minnie Riperton - Lovin' You (Live 1975)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7MqTrXwojk&NR=1 | format= | medium= | language= | trans_title= | publisher=[[The Midnight Special (TV series)]]| location= | archiveurl= | archivedate = | accessdate =September 25, 2011| time=03:07| id= | isbn= | oclc= | quote=Maya, Maya, Maya| ref= }} Riperton died on July 12, 1979, at 31, from [[breast cancer]]. Rudolph's godmother was R&B singer [[Teena Marie]].{{cite news |url=http://marquee.blogs.cnn.com/2010/12/28/top-10-little-known-facts-about-teena-marie/?hpt=T2 |title=Top 10 little known facts about Teena Marie |date=December 28, 2010 |work=[[CNN Entertainment]] |accessdate=May 13, 2011}} In 1990, Rudolph graduated from [[Crossroads School (Santa Monica, California)|Crossroads School]] in [[Santa Monica, California]], where she became friendly with fellow students [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] and [[Jack Black]],{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/05/maya-rudolph-show-throwback-to-carol-burnett.html |title=The New Carol Burnett: Maya Rudolph on Fulfilling Her Variety-Show Dream |publisher=Vulture |date=May 8, 2014 |first=Alex |last=Morris |accessdate=August 17, 2014 }} and continued her education at the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]], in whose residential college [[Porter College]] she lived, graduating in 1995 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[photography]].{{cite web| title=Maya Rudolph Biography| url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/maya-rudolph/bio/190553| work=[[TVGuide.com]]| accessdate=May 15, 2011}} ==Career== {{BLP sources section|date=January 2015}} ===''Saturday Night Live''=== In May 2000, Rudolph joined the cast of ''Saturday Night Live'' as a featured player for the final three episodes of the 1999–2000 season, after a stint as a member of [[The Groundlings]] [[improvisational theatre|improv]] troupe, where she met future ''Saturday Night Live'' cast member [[Will Forte]]. Rudolph's musical talents were frequently employed on ''Saturday Night Live''. She sang as [[Beyoncé|Beyoncé Knowles]] in the ''[[Prince (artist)|Prince]] Show'' sketches, as the "Space Creature" in the ''Gays in Space'' sketches, except for the one on the season 31 episode hosted by [[Peter Sarsgaard]], because it aired around the time Rudolph was on maternity leave. Forte substituted for her during that episode. Her ability to change her looks and her command of many accents also led to her playing an unusually wide range of ethnicities on the show, often with only a change of wigs. As "Nuni Shoener", Rudolph, along with [[Fred Armisen]], created a couple from an unspecified Scandinavian country, who have unplaceable accents and bewilderingly foreign manners. Rudolph was also able to play male characters such as [[Scott Joplin]], [[Justin Guarini]], and [[Mario Vazquez]]. Her final episode as a cast member was on November 3, 2007, with host [[Brian Williams]] and musical guest [[Feist (singer)|Feist]], the last episode before the writers' strike. She returned on October 25, 2008, in a featured guest appearance as [[Michelle Obama]] and sang a duet with [[Kenan Thompson]] about [[Amy Poehler]]'s newborn. She also appeared in the 2008 Christmas episode, where she reprised her role in the sketch Bronx Beat, with Amy Poehler. She also appeared in two sketches in the 2008–09 season finale with [[Will Ferrell]]. She appeared in a [[Weekend Update Thursday]] sketch during the fall 2009–10 season as Oprah Winfrey speaking on behalf of [[Chicago]]'s bid for the [[2016 Olympics]]. She also appeared on the show in May 2010 to perform in skits including "The Manuel Ortiz Show" with [[Betty White]]. She returned to ''Saturday Night Live'' for the season 36 premiere, hosted by Amy Poehler, performing the "Bronx Beat" sketch and that same season for episode 700, hosted by Tina Fey.{{Cite news |last =McGlynn|first =Katla |title = 'SNL': Pregnant Tina Fey & Maya Rudolph Sing Duet About Doin' It | work=[[Huffington Post|www.huffingtonpost.com]] |date = May 8, 2011|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/08/snl-pregnant-tina-fey-maya-rudolph-sing-duet_n_859117.html | accessdate =May 9, 2011}} On February 18, 2012 she returned to ''Saturday Night Live'' as a host for the first time and reprised her roles in sketches such as "Bronx Beat". She once again returned to ''SNL'' for the Christmas episode hosted by Tina Fey and Amy Poehler on December 19, 2015, reprising her role in the "Bronx Beat" sketch.{{cite web|url=https://people.com/tv/amy-poehler-reunites-with-maya-rudolph-in-bronx-beat/|title=Amy Poehler Reunites with Maya Rudolph to Bring 'Bronx Beat' Back to SNL – and They Aren't Fans of Star Wars|date=December 20, 2015|work=People|first=Char|last=Adams|accessdate=February 25, 2019}} She appeared on the [[Saturday Night Live (season 41)|41st-season finale]] (hosted by [[Fred Armisen]]) as [[Dilma Rousseff]] on ''[[Weekend Update]]''. In the [[Saturday Night Live (season 45)|45th-season premiere]], she appeared in a town hall sketch as Senator and presidential candidate [[Kamala Harris]] (D-CA).{{cite web |last1=DeSantis |first1=Rachel |title=Kamala Harris Responds After Maya Rudolph Hilariously Spoofs Her on Saturday Night Live |url=https://people.com/politics/kamala-harris-responds-maya-rudolph-spoof-saturday-night-live/amp/ |website=People |accessdate=October 2, 2019 |date=September 30, 2019}} ====Characters==== Rudolph's characters on the show have included "Attorney Glenda Goodwin" and "Megan" from the "Wake Up, Wakefield!" sketches. Rudolph did a number of celebrity impressions on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' during her tenure, including [[Amanda Byram]], [[Ananda Lewis]], [[Barbra Streisand]], [[Bern Nadette Stanis]] (as [[Thelma Evans]] on ''[[Good Times]]''), [[Beyoncé]], [[Charo]], [[Christina Aguilera]], [[Condoleezza Rice]], [[Darcel Wynne]], [[Diana Ross]], [[Dilma Rousseff]], [[Donatella Versace]], [[Donna Fargo]], [[Emily Robison]], [[Fredricka Whitfield]], [[Free (rapper)|Free]], [[Gayle King]], [[Orda Khan]], [[Griselda Blanco]], [[Halle Berry]], [[Ivanka Trump]], [[Ja'net Dubois]] (as [[Willona Woods]] on ''[[Good Times]]''), [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Joyce Irby|Joyce "Fenderella" Irby]], [[Justin Guarini]], [[Kara Saun]], [[Kamala Harris]], [[La Toya Jackson]], [[Lisa Kudrow]], [[Lisa Ling]], [[Liza Minnelli]], [[Lucy Liu]], [[Lynda Lopez]], [[Macy Gray]], [[Mario Vasquez]], [[Mary Roach]], [[Maya Angelou]], [[Melinda Doolittle]], [[Melissa Stark]], [[Michelle Obama]], [[Mýa]], [[Nelly Furtado]], [[Omarosa Manigault]], [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Paris Hilton]], [[Patti LaBelle]], [[Phylicia Rashad]] (as [[Clair Huxtable]] on ''[[The Cosby Show]]''), [[Rocsi]], [[Scott Joplin]], [[Teresa Heinz]], [[Tera Patrick]], [[Tina Turner]], [[Tyra Banks]], [[Valerie Simpson]], [[Vanessa Hudgens]] (as [[Gabriella Montez]] from ''[[High School Musical 3]]''), [[Wanda Sykes]] and [[Whitney Houston]]. '''Recurring characters''' {{Div col|colwidth=}} *Appreciante *Britanica of [[Gemini's Twin]] *Casey *Charli Coffee *Cocktail Waitress *Donatella Versace *Glenda Goodwin *Jackie *Jodi Deitz (one of the co-hosts of "Bronx Beat") *Leilani Burke *Megan (one of the co-hosts of "Wake Up, Wakefield!") *Mrs. Denmont *Nuni Schoener *Patti Sylviac *Rebecca *Space Creature {{Div col end}} ===Television and film=== In addition to her work on ''Saturday Night Live'', Rudolph has appeared on other television shows, including the [[CBS]] [[medical drama]] series ''[[City of Angels (2000 TV series)|City of Angels]]'' and ''[[Chicago Hope]]''. She had small parts in ''[[Chuck & Buck]]'', ''[[Gattaca]]'', ''[[As Good as It Gets]]'', ''[[Duplex (film)|Duplex]]'' and ''[[Duets (film)|Duets]]''; she was also a music supervisor for ''Duets''. Her first prominent film role came in 2006 with ''[[A Prairie Home Companion (film)|A Prairie Home Companion]]''. Earlier, she had costarred with [[Luke Wilson]] in the 2005 [[Mike Judge]] sci-fi comedy ''[[Idiocracy]]'', although that film was shelved until September 2006 and then only given a limited release. She also guest-starred as Rapunzel in the [[DreamWorks Animation|DreamWorks]] animated film ''[[Shrek the Third]]''. She guest-starred as Julia in ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[The Homer of Seville]]". Rudolph guest-starred as character Athena Scooberman in NBC's ''[[Kath & Kim (American TV series)|Kath & Kim]]'', and starred in the film ''[[Away We Go (film)|Away We Go]]'' with ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]'' star [[John Krasinski]]. In 2010, she appeared in ''[[Grown Ups (film)|Grown Ups]]'' starring [[Adam Sandler]], where she played the wife of [[Chris Rock]]'s character. In 2011, she appeared in ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' with ''Saturday Night Live'' colleague [[Kristen Wiig]], and in 2013 she played a supporting role in ''[[The Way, Way Back]]'' as the girlfriend of [[Sam Rockwell]]'s character. She co-starred in the NBC sitcom ''[[Up All Night (TV series)|Up All Night]]'', with [[Christina Applegate]] and [[Will Arnett]]. Rudolph's self-titled [[variety show]] television pilot aired on May 19, 2014,{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Scott|title=Maya Rudolph looks to spice up NBC with a variety show|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-et-st-maya-rudolph-20140519-story.html#page=1|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=May 19, 2014|date=May 19, 2014}} but the show did not go beyond that. It was later announced that she would star in an NBC variety series ''[[Maya & Marty]]'' with [[Martin Short]],{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/maya-rudolph-martin-short-variety-show-nbc-lorne-michaels-1201705072/|title=NBC Greenlights Maya Rudolph-Martin Short Variety Show, Targets May Premiere (EXCLUSIVE)|accessdate=February 13, 2016|date=February 12, 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Cynthia|last=Littleton}} which debuted on May 31, 2016. Her next series, ''[[Forever (2018 TV series)|Forever]]'', premiered on September 14, 2018 on [[Amazon Video]].{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/forever-trailer-maya-rudolph-fred-armisen-catherine-keener-amazon-1202438590/|title='Forever' Trailer: Maya Rudolph, Fred Armisen, A Ski Trip & A Changed Life In Amazon Comedy|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Erik|last=Pederson|date=August 2, 2018|accessdate=August 2, 2018}} Also in 2018, she began doing [[Ruby Tuesday (restaurant)|Ruby Tuesday]] and [[Seventh Generation Inc.|Seventh Generation]] commercials. In 2019 she appeared as the mother in ''[[The Lego Movie 2: The Second Part]]''. ===Music=== Prior to joining ''Saturday Night Live'', Rudolph was a [[backing singer]] (1995–99) and briefly a keyboardist in the band [[The Rentals]], with whom she toured for a short time. She also appears in the music videos of the songs "Waiting" and "Please Let That Be You". She sang backing vocals for "Barcelona" and "My Head Is in the Sun", both from the album ''[[Seven More Minutes]]''. In 2004, she recorded a track with The Rentals frontman [[Matt Sharp]], including a [[cover version|cover]] of [[Tegan and Sara]]'s "Not Tonight". Rudolph also performed "Together In Pooping" and "Little Roundworm" with [[Triumph the Insult Comic Dog]] (Robert Smigel) on his album ''[[Come Poop With Me]]''. She is in a [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] cover band called Princess with her friend [[Gretchen Lieberum]].{{cite web|url=http://people.com/tv/prince-dead-dangelo-performs-with-maya-rudolph-gretchen-lieberum/|title=D'Angelo Performs Prince Tribute with Maya Rudolph and Gretchen Lieberum on ''Tonight Show''|date=April 27, 2016|work=People}} ==Personal life== Rudolph has been in a relationship with [[Paul Thomas Anderson]] since 2001.{{cite news |url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/maya-rudolph-baby-1035462.aspx |title=It's a Boy for Maya Rudolph and Paul Thomas Anderson |date=July 19, 2011|work=TV Guide |accessdate=September 10, 2013|first=Kate|last=Stanhope}} They live together with four children.{{Cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/maya-rudolph-welcomes-fourth-child-2013109|title=Maya Rudolph Welcomes Fourth Child!|website=Us Weekly|access-date=April 7, 2016|date=September 10, 2013}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !
